Adult Monarchs feed on flower nectar
by sucking it through a tube
called the proboscis.

North American Monarchs are the
only butterflies that migrate such
a long distance â€“ up to 3,000 miles!

Monarchs prefer warm climates.
If they are dry they can survive freezing
temperatures but if they get wet and
the temperature drops they will die.

Monarchs come from eggs
which hatch caterpillars who feed
on milkweed plants.

Monarchs fly between
12 and 25 miles per hour.

Monarchs who live west of the
Rocky Mountains migrate to
southern California in winter,
while those who live east of
the Rockies head to Mexico.

In Mexico they roost in trees in
HUGE groups that may have
MILLIONS of butterflies!

Monarchs smell with their antennas
and tasted with their feet!

The feet have receptors called tarsi
that taste the sweet nectar.

Monarchs use updrafts
of warm air (called thermals)
to allow them to glide
so they can conserve energy.

A large monarch caterpillar
can devour an entire milkweed plant
in less than four minutes.

Caterpillar poop is called frass.
They make a lot of frass!

Monarchs are poisonous
to many animals.
The poison comes from the
milkweed they eat which make
the Monarchs taste terrible!

Are you sure you
want to quit?
